an3.14:4.1: “Mendicants, even a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king, does not wield power without having their own king.”
an3.14:4.2: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha:
an3.14:4.3: “But who is the king of the wheel-turning monarch, the just and principled king?”
an3.14:4.4: “It is principle, monk,” said the Buddha.
an3.14:4.5: “Monk, a wheel-turning monarch provides just protection and security for his court, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as his flag, banner, and authority.
an3.14:5.1: He provides just protection and security for his aristocrats, vassals, troops, brahmins and householders, people of town and country, ascetics and brahmins, beasts and birds.
an3.14:5.2: When he has done this, he wields power only in a principled manner.
an3.14:5.3: And this power cannot be undermined by any human enemy.
an3.14:6.1: So too, monk, a Realized One, a Perfect One, a fully awakened Buddha, a just and principled king, provides just protection and security regarding bodily actions, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as his flag, banner, and authority.
an3.14:6.2: ‘This kind of bodily action should be cultivated. This kind of bodily action should not be cultivated.’
an3.14:7.1: Furthermore, a Realized One … provides just protection and security regarding verbal actions, saying:
an3.14:7.2: ‘This kind of verbal action should be cultivated. This kind of verbal action should not be cultivated.’ … And regarding mental actions:
an3.14:7.3: ‘This kind of mental action should be cultivated. This kind of mental action should not be cultivated.’
an3.14:8.1: And when a Realized One, a Perfect One, a fully awakened Buddha has provided just protection and security regarding actions of body, speech, and mind, he rolls forth the supreme Wheel of Dharma.
an3.14:8.2: And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.”
